author: Sunil Soren Majhi
title: Seabourn Pursuit Unveils Century-Old Mystery with Discovery of Lost Shipwreck in Chile
text:
Seabourn, renowned for its ultra-luxury voyages and expedition travel, has made a groundbreaking discovery during a submarine dive near Alejandro Selkirk Island in Chile‚Äôs Juan Fern√°ndez Archipelago. On October 14, 2024, the Seabourn Pursuit, the brand‚Äôs latest purpose-built expedition vessel, uncovered the long-lost Titania, a German supply ship that had been missing for 110 years. Resting 95 meters beneath the ocean‚Äôs surface, this astonishing find marks the first sighting of the Titania since it was deliberately sunk in 1914.
‚ÄúExperiences like these are a testament to the spirit of expedition, and this discovery is nothing short of historic,‚Äù said Robin West, vice president and general manager of expeditions at Seabourn. ‚ÄúSeabourn‚Äôs expeditions and particularly our submarine explorations often take our guests to places where no other human has ever explored. I am so incredibly proud of our expedition team for delivering this once-in-a-lifetime and truly unforgettable ‚ÄòSeabourn Moment‚Äô to our guests and the local community on Selkirk Island.‚Äù
The discovery of the Titania was made possible by the submarine team‚Äôs dedicated research and close collaboration with local communities, creating a truly one-of-a-kind experience for guests. Led by Submarine Pilot Mauricio Fernandez, the team‚Äîcomprised of Kieran Buckley, Henrik Enckell, and Isaac Yebra‚Äîpartnered with local fisherman Gino Perez, who had long heard tales about the Titania‚Äôs possible location. Perez joined the dive, assisting the team in pinpointing the suspected wreck site. Under ideal weather conditions, the team uncovered the Titania 95 meters below the surface, roughly 4.25 nautical miles off Selkirk‚Äôs northwest coast. Following the discovery, the island‚Äôs harbor master confirmed that no previous diver or submarine had ever explored the wreck.
Fernandez shared how the emotion in the submarine was palpable. ‚ÄúWe were there witnessing history, and our guests had the chance to be a part of this discovery of Titania and the first to see this ship after she sank to the bottom of the ocean 110 years ago. This was truly a special moment of discovery and a perfect example of how Seabourn expeditions continue to provide our guests with incredible Seabourn Moments throughout each journey.‚Äù
Guests described the feeling when they saw Titania for the first time: ‚ÄúIt was almost magical. It really was quite extraordinary,‚Äù said Irene Blum, a guest who was in the submarine during the discovery.
It was particularly emotional for Perez, who shared, ‚ÄúI imagined this ship so many times and now I can see where she is, how she looks like and how she is resting at the bottom. Thank you so much, my father manages this sector of the island, this means a lot to us and our family history. This is extraordinary.‚Äù
The Titania was deliberately scuttled on November 19, 1914, and stories of the wreck have been passed down through generations. Although fishermen occasionally found metal fragments in their lobster traps, believed to be from the vessel, the wreck‚Äôs exact location had remained undiscovered until now.
Unveiling the South Pacific: Seabourn Pursuit‚Äôs Extraordinary Itineraries
During one of Seabourn Pursuit‚Äôs remarkable South Pacific voyages, a historic discovery was made, further enhancing the allure of these adventurous journeys. Spanning over 4,000 miles, these itineraries take guests on an exploration of the rich and remote regions of Melanesia, French Polynesia, and San Antonio, Chile. Along the way, passengers have the unique opportunity to explore some of the world‚Äôs most isolated treasures, such as the Juan Fernandez Archipelago off Chile‚Äôs coast, spend time on the enigmatic Easter Island, visit the volcanic Pitcairn Islands, and venture into the remote Yasawa Islands of Fiji.
Building on the success of these thrilling adventures, Seabourn Pursuit is set to offer similar deployments in 2025, featuring four exclusive voyages. These include two 20-day journeys, one departing from San Antonio, Chile to Papeete, Tahiti on March 18, 2025, and another from Papeete to San Antonio on October 10, 2025. Additionally, an 18-day voyage from Papeete to Sydney is scheduled to depart on April 7, 2025, and a 16-day Remote Shores of New Guinea & Indonesia voyage will set sail from Sydney to Darwin on April 24, 2025.
Unforgettable Submarine Adventures with Seabourn
A highlight of Seabourn Pursuit‚Äôs expeditions is the opportunity to embark on unforgettable submarine experiences. Both Seabourn Pursuit and its sister ship, Seabourn Venture, are equipped with two custom-built, state-of-the-art submarines designed to offer guests an extraordinary perspective beneath the ocean‚Äôs surface. These submarines allow for a once-in-a-lifetime exploration of surreal underwater landscapes, from the icy depths of Antarctic waters to the vibrant, marine life-filled reefs in tropical seas.
In select destinations, guests can dive into unexplored locations, possibly being among the first humans to set eyes on these hidden realms. Seated in two clear acrylic spheres, flanking the pilot‚Äôs station, passengers enjoy an awe-inspiring view with virtually undistorted sightlines in every direction. Each sphere contains three passenger seats mounted on a rotating platform, allowing for the best possible viewing experience.
Submarine dives are offered on select itineraries, including Seabourn Pursuit‚Äôs South Pacific sailings from March through October 2025, and are available for an additional charge. Operated by highly trained pilots, Seabourn‚Äôs submarines are built to the highest safety standards, certified by Lloyd‚Äôs Register and undergoing annual external inspections. These advanced submarines are designed with multiple safety features, including a safety buoy and a maximum diving depth of 300 meters (less than 1,000 feet). Throughout each dive, a surface boat remains in constant communication with the submarine, ensuring a safe and seamless experience.
A New Level of Adventure Awaits
With its upcoming 2025 voyages and unparalleled submarine explorations, Seabourn Pursuit offers guests the ultimate opportunity to experience the wonders of the South Pacific like never before. Whether discovering historic shipwrecks or witnessing the vibrant marine life in untouched underwater worlds, Seabourn continues to set the standard for ultra-luxury adventure travel, providing guests with experiences they will treasure for a lifetime.

title: Soup's on! Warm your body and soul with these brilliant bowls from Las Vegas
text:
When we‚Äôre feeling under the weather, down or otherwise out of sorts, we turn to soup to help bring us back up. The ultimate comfort comes in the form of a steaming hot bowl. And lucky for us, Las Vegas offers a variety of restaurants proffering hearty, restorative options. Here are a few of our favorites.
Shang Beef Noodle Soup at Shang Artisan Noodle
Shang‚Äôs beef noodle soup hits like an internal hug. Hours of braising have turned the chunks of brisket into exquisitely tender bites, falling apart in a deep red, rich and meaty broth. The hand-pulled or knife-cut noodles are your ticket to absorbing all that flavor, and don‚Äôt skip the bok choy that floats above the tangle of noodles, inviting you to break up the richness with its crisp texture. It‚Äôs a full-bodied bowl of comfort that‚Äôll put you right again. $19, multiple locations, shangartisannoodle.com. ‚ÄìGabriela Rodriguez
Carne en su Jugo at La Vecindad
When it comes to flavor, this Guadalajara favorite dethrones most traditional stews. Simmering its meats in tomatillo sauce, serrano peppers and spring onion for tangy, salsa-like consistency, carne en su jugo shocks the palate in the tastiest way possible. Pinto beans and crispy bacon build upon an already wonderful marriage of textures to the point where this hearty meal becomes something you savor rather than slurp. $19, 953 E. Sahara Ave. #E-27, lavecindadlv.com. ‚ÄìAmber Sampson
Tom Kha Kai at Weera Thai
Chicken soup is universally recognized as a remedy for whatever you‚Äôre going through, but this version at one of the Valley‚Äôs top Thai restaurants offers a knockout punch of flavor to match its possibly medicinal properties. Tons of lemongrass and ginger lay the groundwork; fresh veggies like tomatoes, onions and mushroom boost each beautiful bite; dashes of fish sauce multiply the savory factor; and coconut milk makes the rest of your day a silky smooth ride. Even if you‚Äôre dining at Weera alone, we recommend ordering the large hot pot of this stuff; you‚Äôll want more when you get home. $14-$21, multiple locations, weerathai.com. ‚ÄìBrock Radke
Tomato Bisque at Herbs & Rye
You come to Herbs and Rye for the cocktails, you stay for the tomato bisque. This velvety, creamy and downright dreamy appetizer‚Äîpaired with a buttery grilled cheese‚Äîhas comfort written all over it. Drizzled in a savory basil oil, this soup secures points for its rich aromatics and smooth consistency. But it‚Äôs the grilled cheese dunking‚Äîthat salty clash of toasted bread and tangy tomato‚Äîthat makes this an undisputed cold weather duo worth relishing. $15, 3713 W. Sahara Ave., herbsandrye.com. ‚ÄìAmber Sampson
RB Signature Ramen at Ramen Boys
Underscoring Ramen Boys‚Äô most popular dish is its savory fusion of chicken and pork broth. That union delivers a well-balanced ratio of creamy thickness to a bowl which could otherwise be overpowered by richness or understated by too light of a texture. It‚Äôs instantly warming and almost toe-curlingly good. Tender cuts of chashu pork, supple and savory, also soak up all that umami flavor, winding together with springy noodles, soy-cured egg and the pleasant crunch of green onion. $18, 3650 S. Decatur Blvd. #3, bumbybox.com. ‚ÄìAmber Sampson

author: VOA Learning English
title: Researchers: Protecting 1% of Earth‚Äôs Surface Would Save Rare Wildlife
text:
Embed share Researchers: Protecting 1% of Earth‚Äôs Surface Would Save Rare Wildlife by VOA - Voice of America English News Embed share The code has been copied to your clipboard. The URL has been copied to your clipboard Share on Facebook Share on Twitter No media source currently available
0:00 0:05:29 0:00 Direct link 128 kbps | MP3 64 kbps | MP3 Pop-out player A recent report by environmental researchers says that protecting 1.2 percent of the Earth‚Äôs land surface could prevent most extinctions.
Extinction is the permanent disappearance of an animal or plant from the Earth.
The researchers estimated that such an expansion of nature preserves would cost about $263 billion.
In 2022, United Nations delegates to the COP15 meeting in Montreal, Canada, promised to protect 30 percent of the Earth‚Äôs surface by 2030. The U.N. calls the promise the ‚Äú30-by-30 target.‚Äù It aims to protect plants and animals severely affected by climate change, pollution, and habitat destruction.
In October, U.N. delegates will gather for a COP16 biodiversity meeting in Colombia to discuss plans for reaching the 30-by-30 goal.
FILE - This photo of the endangered kagu was taken at the Preservation and Research Center in Yokohama, Japan, Oct. 25, 2010. (REUTERS/Yuriko Nakao) The recent study was published in Frontiers in Science. In it, the researchers aimed to identify the highest value areas around the world. Carlos Peres said he hopes the areas identified will be included in protection plans. Peres was a co-writer of the study and is a conservation ecology expert at the University of East Anglia in Britain.
Perese said, "Most countries do not actually have a strategy .‚Äù
He said, "The 30-by-30 targets still lack a lot of details because it doesn't actually say what 30 percent should be protected."
The study's proposed protections would cover an additional 1.6 million square kilometers. This is an area about one fifth the size of the United States. The study includes 16,825 sites that are home to rare and threatened wildlife.
FILE - These endangered Mexican gray wolves rest at the Museo del Desierto in Saltillo, Mexico, July 1, 2020. (REUTERS/Daniel Becerril/File Photo) It is estimated that nearly 16 percent of the world‚Äôs surface already has some level of protection.
The study estimated that the cost of purchasing land by governments would be about $263 billion. Many of these areas include private property and would be bought at current market values over the next five years.
"Time is not on our side,‚Äù Peres said, ‚Äúbecause it will become increasingly more expensive and more difficult to set aside additional protected areas.‚Äù
Most of the cost of creating protected areas is in buying the land. The study did not consider the costs for policing and maintaining the nature preserves.
FILE - The waldrapp, a critically endangered species, sits inside the breeding aviary cage at the Preservation and Research Center in Yokohama, south of Tokyo, October 25, 2010. (REUTERS/Yuriko Nakao/File Photo) About three-quarters of the sites are tropical forests. The Philippines, Brazil, and Indonesia are home to more than half of the high-valued areas.
Russia is the one country with the most high-valued areas. The study said about 138,000 square kilometers should be the target of conservation.
Several African countries are also at the top of the list. Madagascar has the fourth-highest number of areas. And the Democratic Republic of Congo has the largest area targeted for conservation in Africa.
The United States is among the top 30 countries in the study. The study said about 0.6 percent of the U.S. should be targeted for conservation. That is an area about the size of the state of Delaware.
The researchers only considered land and freshwater areas. They did not consider oceans or marine protected areas. The study also did not include kinds of animals such as invertebrates, or animals without a backbone, like insects.
The U.S.-based nonprofit group One Earth paid for the study.
I‚Äôm Anna Matteo.
Jake Spring reported this story for Reuters. Anna Matteo adapted it for VOA Learning English.

title: The warmest December in Chatham County history
text: The popular image of an idyllic December is one of white Christmases, hot chocolate retreats, snow-capped conifers, and cozy, cold-weather activities. But not every December lives up to those expectations. Most of the continental U.S. will experience its peak winter cold weather in January and February . Officially, winter doesn't even start until Dec. 21. Across the U.S., the average December temperature from 1901-2000 was right above freezing point, at 32.68 F. Yearly temperatures can be compared to this 20th-century long-term average to find how uncommon a year's December climate was. The nation's warmest December on record was 2021, when the average temperature reached 6.66 F above the long-term average, at 39.34 F. December 2022 was closer to the previous century's average for the U.S. overall, at 33.08 F. The average temperature in Chatham County, Georgia from 1901-2000 was 51.0. The diverse climates of the U.S. mean residents can experience a range of holiday weather without breaking out their passports. Within the continental U.S., Monroe County, Florida, at the Southeast tip of the state, reported the highest average December temperature during the past century at 67.6 F. On the other end of the spectrum was Roseau County, Minnesota, bordering Canada, at 7.2 F. However, across both sides of the extremes, temperatures are warming. While that doesn't mean every December will be warmer than the last or the prior century's average, it does mean long-term temperature averages will continue to inch up the thermometer. When did Chatham County, Georgia experience its warmest December? To find out, Stacker used data from the National Centers for Environmental Information to identify the 15 Decembers with the highest average temperature since 1895. Also included is how that year's temperature compared to the 1901-2000 average. Read on to see if you lived through the warmest December in Chatham County, Georgia history.

author: Saboor Bayat
title: Revolutionizing Urban Mobility: Manaus Adopts Optibus Software for Sustainable Public Transportation
text:
In a world where cities grapple with the challenges of urbanization and environmental sustainability, a groundbreaking stride has been made in Manaus, Brazil. The city, known for its lush landscapes and as the heart of the Amazon region, has embarked on a transformative journey by adopting Optibus software for its public transportation system. This move not only marks a significant leap towards sustainable urban mobility but also celebrates a global milestone, with Manaus becoming the 5,000th city worldwide to integrate this advanced technology. Today, we delve into how this Israeli software company is revolutionizing public transportation in Manaus, aligning with the city's ambitious Smart Cities Plan.
The Dawn of a New Era in Public Transportation
At the core of Manaus' urban innovation is the adoption of Optibus' cutting-edge software, designed to plan and operate a more sustainable and efficient public transportation network. The software's deployment in Manaus is a testament to the city's commitment to embracing artificial intelligence (AI) and machine learning optimization algorithms. This strategic move is poised to enhance the management of the city's entire public transportation system, overseen by the Union of Passenger Transport Companies of the State of Amazonas (Sinetram). Through the use of Optibus' route planning, crew and vehicle scheduling, and Timetable Optimization products, Manaus is set to pioneer the first public transportation network in the Amazonas region powered by AI.
Transforming Urban Mobility with Innovation
The integration of Optibus software in Manaus is a critical component of the city's Smart Cities Plan. By leveraging AI and machine learning, the city aims to improve service efficiency across 278 routes, offering smarter, more adaptable transportation services to its residents. This initiative not only underscores Manaus' leadership in technological adoption within the region but also highlights the global industry's shift towards more sustainable and efficient public transportation services. The partnership with Optibus is expected to reshape how cities around the world approach urban mobility challenges, setting a new benchmark for innovation and sustainability in public transportation.
A Global Milestone for Optibus and Urban Sustainability
The adoption of Optibus software by Manaus is more than a local achievement; it represents a significant milestone for the Israeli software company, now boasting its presence in 5,000 cities worldwide. This achievement underscores the growing recognition of the need for sustainable and efficient public transportation solutions across the globe. Optibus' success in Manaus and beyond exemplifies how technology can be harnessed to make urban environments more livable, resilient, and environmentally friendly. As cities continue to expand and evolve, the role of innovative solutions like Optibus in shaping the future of public transportation becomes increasingly crucial.
In conclusion, the partnership between Manaus and Optibus signifies a bold step forward in the quest for sustainable urban development. By integrating advanced AI and machine learning technologies into its public transportation system, Manaus not only sets a precedent for cities in the Amazonas region but also joins a global movement towards smarter, more efficient urban mobility solutions. As we witness this historic collaboration, it is clear that the path to sustainable urbanization is paved with innovation, determination, and a vision for a greener, more connected world.
